title: Florida trappers capture record-setting python in...
text:
Florida trappers have captured a record-setting 98-pound Burmese python that's over 18 feet long.

Couple Cynthia Downer and Jonathan Lopez caught the massive beast on September 22 at the Big Cypress National Preserve in Ochopee, Florida.

The two were a part of the Python Action Team, a group of trappers removing the invasive snakes from the Everglades.

The female python measured 18 feet 4 inches (5.58 meters) and weighed a whopping 98 pounds 10 ounces.

Florida trappers have captured a record-setting Burmese python that's 18 feet 4 inches long and weighs a whopping 98 pounds 10 ounces

Cynthia Downer and Jonathan Lopez caught the massive beast on September 22 at the Big Cypress National Preserve in Ochopee, Florida as a part of the Python Action Team, a group of trappers removing the invasive snakes from the Everglades

According to the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission it's the largest python captured at the preserve, located west of Miami.

The agency says it is the second-largest python ever caught in the wild in Florida, just four inches shorter than the record holder.

The commission says hunting female Burmese pythons is critical because they add between 30 and 60 hatchlings each time they breed.

Cynthia Downer shared this post on Facebook posing with the snake after she found it

She captioned her post: 'Here is how 18'4" of python looks curled up like a cinnamon roll'

This is how the snake camouflaged in the grass before Lopez picked it up

She said: 'I need his support, driving skills, catching skills, quick thinking, and physical strength just as much as he needed my crazy arse to convince him it was a good idea to pull all nighters driving around in the deep dark Everglades looking for snakes'

Cynthia Downer shared a post on Facebook showing the snake hiding in the grass before they picked it up and posing with the massive beast.

'Here is how 18'4" of python looks curled up like a cinnamon roll,' she wrote.

She credited her team work with her husband Jonathan to their success in trapping the snake.

'I need his support, driving skills, catching skills, quick thinking, and physical strength just as much as he needed my crazy arse to convince him it was a good idea to pull all nighters driving around in the deep dark Everglades looking for snakes,' she shared.

The beast was caught at Big Cypress National Preserve in Ochopee, Florida

Pythons are not native to the state and removing them is imperative as they disrupt the native wildlife in the Florida Everglades

The Python Action Team was created to double down and capture the Burmese pythons in south Florida as the snake is not native to the state and was likely introduced as an escaped or released pet.

So far 900 pythons have been captured by the commission.

'Removing 900 pythons is a great milestone for our Python Action Team! These snakes, coupled with the thousands removed by our partners at the National Park Service and the South Florida Water Management District, make a significant impact to protect Florida’s native wildlife.,' Executive Director Eric Sutton said to Fox6.
description: Florida trappers have captured a record-setting  Burmese python that's 18 feet 4 inches long and weighs a whopping 98 pounds 10 ounces at Big Cypress National Preserve in Ochopee.
